H0.text: The mountain range will become faulted as wind and water erosion change it over time.

H1.text: The mountain range will be lifted up is the statement that best describes how a mountain range changes over time from wind and water erosion.

H2.text: The mountain range will form craters when it changes over time from wind and water erosion.

H3.text: The mountain range will become rounded over time as a result of wind and water erosion.

A4.text: glacial erosion controls the maximum height of mountains, as the relief between mountain peaks and the snow line are generally confined to altitudes less than 1500 m

A5.text: the erosion caused by glaciers worldwide erodes mountains so effectively that the term glacial buzzsaw has become widely used, which describes the limiting effect of glaciers on the height of mountain ranges

A6.text: Water is the principal agent of chemical weathering, converting many primary minerals to clay minerals or hydrated oxides via reactions collectively described as hydrolysis.

A7.text: Frost weathering is the most important form of physical weathering. Next in importance is wedging by plant roots, which sometimes enter cracks in rocks and pry them apart.

A8.text: Denudation is the geological process in which moving water, ice, wind, and waves erode the Earth's surface, leading to a reduction in elevation and in relief of landforms and landscapes.

A9.text: Denudation rates are usually much lower than the rates of uplift and average orogeny rates can be eight times the maximum average denudation.
